title: SB 1073
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, with an adjustment factor of 0 percent unless specified otherwise in the annual Budget Act. The earned income tax credit adjustment factor for taxable years starting January 1, 2015, is 0 percent unless specified in the annual Budget Act. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage for eligible individuals with qualifying children are as follows: 1 child - 34%, 2 children - 40%, 3 or more children - 45%. The earned income tax credit percentages and phaseout percentages for eligible individuals with qualifying children are as follows: 1 child - 34%, 2 children - 40%, 3 or more children - 45%. The earned income amount and phaseout amount for eligible individuals without qualifying children are $3,290. For those with 1 child, it is $4,940, and for 2 or more children, it is $6,935. Certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are modified for these calculations. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified for earned income tax credit calculations in this state. The earned income amount for eligible individuals without qualifying children is increased to $3,400. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified for earned income tax credit calculations in this state. The earned income amount for eligible individuals without qualifying children is increased to $3,400. Additionally, inflation adjustments for taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2016, will be recomputed annually. If the credit amount exceeds the tax liability, the excess will be credited against other amounts due, with any remaining balance refunded to the taxpayer from the Tax Relief and Refund Account. The Franchise Tax Board can establish rules for this section, exempt from certain requirements for implementing the credit for the 2015 taxable year. Refunded amounts will be treated like federal earned income refunds for benefit eligibility under the Welfare and Institutions Code. The Franchise Tax Board is exempt from specific requirements to implement the credit for the 2015 taxable year. They must include scope, costs, and schedule changes in their next Special Project Report for the Enterprise Data to Revenue Project. The Franchise Tax Board will include scope, costs, and schedule changes related to the California Earned Income Tax Credit in their next Special Project Report. The purpose of the credit is to reduce poverty among working families and individuals in California. The Board will annually report on the number of tax returns claiming the credit, individuals represented, average credit amount, and distribution of credits by dependents and income ranges. The Franchise Tax Board will report on the average credit amount, distribution of credits by dependents and income ranges, and the impact of the California Earned Income Tax Credit on lifting families out of deep poverty. The Franchise Tax Board will provide a written report to various Senate and Assembly committees regarding the California Earned Income Tax Credit. The tax credit will apply to taxable years starting on or after January 1, 2016.
